results.title: Elevator Operator – Courtney Barnett
results.brief_description: Courtney Barnett’s ‘Elevator Operator’ (2016) leans hard into theatrical inspirations like the work of Wes Anderson and features familiar screen faces like Madgda Szubanski, Sleater-Kinney, Tim Rogers, Paul Kelly and Michael Leunig as they travel through the elevator in Melbourne’s Nicholas Building.

constellations_primary.name: Elevator Operator: Up and down, the on-screen gift of elevators
constellations_primary.description: Inspired by Courtney Barnett playing an elevator operator in her hit song of the same name, we look at how they're used on-screen for comedy, drama and suspense, with the small, confined boxes forcing characters to physically confront each other.

results.description: The music video as a mini movie is an enduring concept within the genre, first achieving mainstream popularity with Michael Jackson’s Thriller (1983). This idea was toyed with in Courtney Barnett’s Elevator Operator(2016), which leans hard into theatrical inspirations like the work of Wes Anderson and features familiar screen faces like Madgda Szubanski, Sleater-Kinney, Tim Rogers, Paul Kelly and Michael Leunig as they travel through the elevator in Melbourne’s Nicholas Building.

results.title: Elevator Action
results.brief_description:
Elevator Action (エレベーターアクション Erebētā Akushon) is a 1983 arcade game by Taito. It debuted during the “Golden Age of Arcade Games”. Innovative in gameplay, the game was very popular for many years.

In the game, the player assumes the role of a spy who infiltrates a building filled with elevators. He must collect secret documents from the building and traverse the 30 floors of the building using an increasingly complex series of elevators. The player is pursued by enemy agents who appear from behind closed doors. These agents must be dealt with via force or evasion. Successful completion of a level involves collecting all the secret documents and traversing the building from top to bottom. In the lower floors of the building, the elevator systems are so complex that some puzzle-solving skills are needed.

The game was available as a standard upright cabinet The controls consist of a 4-way joystick and two buttons, one for “shoot” and the other for jumping and kicking. The maximum number of players is two, alternating turns. The graphics are extremely simple, 2D color graphics and in-game music was composed by musician Yoshio Imamura. The game was followed by a sequel, Elevator Action II (also known as Elevator Action Returns).

constellations_other.name: Elevator Operator: Up and down, the on-screen gift of elevators
constellations_other.description: Inspired by Courtney Barnett playing an elevator operator in her hit song of the same name, we look at how they're used on-screen for comedy, drama and suspense, with the small, confined boxes forcing characters to physically confront each other.

results.title: Elevation
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission and Stephen Cummins
results.brief_description: This queer short film begins with two men in bed next to each other. The focus then shifts to the two men encountering each other in an elevator. As they shift in bed, or begin to make love in the lift, the film becomes a celebration of the body and movement: the erotics are a series of dances choreographed to an experimental music score. This is one of a number of short films directed by Stephen Cummins which integrate modern dance with film.

results.title: Elephants: their last stand
results.brief_description: This film is about the conflict between people and elephants. In the Samburu district of Kenya, herds of elephants have raided farms, trampled crops and imperilled a struggling people’s way of life. Unfortunately there is no easy solution to the problem of whether to eliminate the elephants or to protect them as part of the country’s unique heritage.

results.title: Elephants
results.creator_credit: Coronet Films, Bill Walker and Mel Waskin
results.brief_description: Shows the daily activities of elephants, such as eating leaves from trees, drinking and bathing in water. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Elephants
results.brief_description: The setting of this film is a farm where elephants are trained as circus performers. The animals are shown eating, bathing and doing their tricks.

results.title: Elephant theatre (K)
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Sabrina Schmid
results.brief_description: One man has built a little theatre which he can hold in the palm of his hand. It reveals a world of its own. Yet there remains one dream to be fulfilled: that some elephants will come to live in it.

results.title: Elephant theatre
results.brief_description: Like an Indian pod filled with tiny ivory elephants, the imaginary hand-size theatre fills with elephants, to the delight of the man who built it.

results.title: Elephant parts
results.brief_description: This highly entertaining, Grammy award-winning video by Mike Nesmith, former member of the 60s band, The Monkees (America’s answer to the Beatles) has it all - music, dance, comedy skits, and a cast of thousands! Using satire, nothing in this video is sacred as Nesmith takes a shot at American culture, politics, the Hollywood movie industry and the music industry, game shows, etc etc. Original, clever, witty, “Elephant parts” features several of Nesmith’s songs (all written, produced and sung by Nesmith) including “Rio”, “Cruisin’”, “Magic”, “Tonight” and “Light”. Contains some b&w scenes.

results.title: Elephant boy
results.creator_credit: London Film Productions, Alexander Korda, Robert Joseph Flaherty and Zoltan Korda
results.brief_description: Based on Kipling”s “Toomai of the Elephants”, with Sabu as little Toomai, son of the Mahout, and Kala Nag, the elephant. Tells the story of a government expedition in search of wild elephants in the state of Mysore. Toomai’s adventures with Kala Nag and the herd of wild elephants finally leads him to be accorded with the same title of his famous grandfather “Toomai of the Elephants”. This film was beset with difficulties from the start. After years of attempting to obtain sufficient finance to film Kipling’s original story, Flaherty found support from Alexander Korda in 1935 and the Flahertys journeyed to India to adopt (from them) a new method of film making - the original practice adopted by Flaherty of “letting the story flow” and absorbing the way of life of native people and their surroundings was not entirely carried out in the case of “Elephant boy”. Whilst much of the film was shot in studios in England, the film is distinguished by beautiful photography and many fine sequences breathing the very atmosphere of India, captured by Flaherty on location
